An irreversible cascade is defined similarly except that active vertices cannot be deactivated. An irreversible dynamic monopoly is a set of seeds that leads all vertices to activation after finitely many rounds of the irreversible cascade with phi = phi(strict)(maj). A set of vertices, S, is said to be convergent if no vertex will ever change its state, from active to inactive or vice versa, once the set of active vertices equals S.
